Author: endergen
Content:
I don't want faster as in more throughput, I want faster as in lower latency.
Imagine if we could actually develop software that could depend on the internet being lower the 1/60th of a second. All the logic we have to do in games hide latency would go away. We would then be able to just pass back and forth input streams and have our simulations sync by exchanging them back and forth. Perhaps 1/120th would be ideal so that both parties feel a sub 1/60th of a second response time.

Author: johSho7w
Content: Well, they do have hardware to seize a running server without shutting it down (by splicing into the power cables/power lines at the wall plate and introducing battery power). I guess you would also need some sort of dead-man trigger. Suggestions?

Author: goodside
Content:
Those interested in the (extensive) science of framing biases in human reasoning will want to consult Kahneman and Tversky's classic "Choices, Values, and Frames": http://amzn.com/0521627494

Yes, it's dry and scholarly and will require that you relearn basic statistics. You want to read it anyway.

Author: tsally
Content:
First of all, not Hacker News. Daily stories about how the police are dumb belong on Reddit. There was no egregious violation of your rights.

Second, what would people say about the police if they allowed a teenager with a mental disability to run into traffic or otherwise hurt himself? It's not an unreasonable assumption that someone running barefoot in the middle of February might have a problem. Barefoot running isn't mainstream. You should just stop next time and clear it up right away. A few quick facts about barefoot running and it will become clear that you don't have a problem. Speeding up probably had them worried you were trying to get away.

Third, good for you for running barefoot. Although it's not ideal, you might want to consider a pair of Nike Free's to protect your feet from glass or other sharp objects [1, 2]. One nasty cut might take you out of running for a week. If you've been running barefoot for a while, go for the 5.0 or the 3.0.

[1] http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoefinder_detail/1,,s6-240-...

[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nike_Free

Author: harpastum
Content:
Personally, all I could think about after reading this article was the song Colors of the Wind from Pocahontas:

    You think I'm an ignorant savage
    And you've been so many places
    I guess it must be so
    But still I cannot see
    If the savage one is me
    How can there be so much that you don't know
    You don't know 

    ...

    But if you walk the footsteps of a stranger
    You'll learn things you never knew you never knew
That seems to pretty precisely describe the two groups: Pocahontas being in the nurse's position, unsure of her own stance, while the English men squarely fit into the egotistical group.

Author: mechanical_fish
Content:
Like so many similar things, from divination to Dungeons and Dragons, the Myers-Briggs is a game designed to provide a structure on which to hang conversations and creative thought. [1] It gives you some ground rules, some traditional starting points, some classic teams to root for (go ENTJ, go!) and an assortment of useful pivots and props that can be artfully used by the participants to steer their conversation as it progresses.

As such, it's quite useful, though I would no more try to defend it as a scientific theory than I would try to defend chess as an accurate representation of medieval battle tactics. [2]

---

[1] You know what would be fun, or at least funny? A Dungeons-and-Dragons version of the Meyers/Briggs. In fact, I think the AD&D alignment system may be more than halfway there already.

[2] Which is not to say that medieval tacticians, to say nothing of modern tacticians, didn't play a lot of games as part of their practice.

Author: davatk
Content:
I should probably stress that I agree with you on pretty much everything except that last sentence.

As for the Miller-Rabin test, it's basically a case where you can get a correct answer with an arbitrarily low probability of error. So I guess the tie in is that just because our decisions are predictable (or at least mostly so), doesn't mean there isn't randomness involved.

I'm starting to suspect that I'm responding to an interpretation you didn't intend, though.

Author: jcnnghm
Content:
People like this shouldn't be writing technical articles.

A 700ms ping would be indicative of severe network problems, especially at that distance. The author is probably experiencing packet loss. Realistic ping times across the country are usually 100ms or so. I can ping most major websites in under 20ms.

DNS can indeed be a bottleneck, but it usually isn't. It's a fairly basic service, and if it's really a problem it's simple stupid to switch to a free provider like google.

Streaming video is not dependent on latency, only throughput.

Dark fiber won't necessarily help. The bottleneck is more realistically in the switching equipment. A single fiber can carry massive amounts of data.

Author: Dove
Content:
It's not tactically worthless. You don't have to dig any deeper than the wikipedia article to learn about its mission:

The ABL was designed for use against tactical ballistic missiles (TBMs). These have a shorter range and fly more slowly than ICBMs. The MDA has recently suggested the ABL might be used against ICBMs during their boost phase. This could require much longer flights to get in position, and might not be possible without flying over hostile territory. Liquid-fueled ICBMs, which have thinner skins, and remain in boost phase longer than TBMs, might be easier to destroy.

If the ABL achieves its design goals, it could destroy liquid-fueled ICBMs up to 600 km away. Tougher solid-fueled ICBM destruction range would likely be limited to 300 km, too short to be useful in many scenarios, according to a 2003 report by the American Physical Society on National Missile Defense.

Upshot being, homeland defense in general, and ICBMs in particular, are not really its mission. It's designed to counter TBMs--that is, artillery. Potentially very long range artillery, but still.

Being able to shoot down artillery from the air with a lot of speed and flexibility could be useful in any number of scenarios. Probably not homeland defense, though. Oceans and all.

>But how many milliseconds does it take the user's computer to parse and load your code once it's arrived?

Nice tests though. Will give it a try on my machine, when I get a bit of time.

Author: _delirium
Content:
On my middling DSL (320 kbps symmetric) there's a lot of pages that take more than 3 seconds to load, especially if you're not using AdBlock. There are some Flash ads that take 5+ seconds to load just by themselves!

The typical for a large corporate site seems to be 4-6 sec for me. I just timed cnn.com and yahoo.com both at 5s total load time, and aol.com at 8s (all in Chrome on Linux).

edit: Found a new winner: foxnews.com consistently takes between 25 and 33 seconds to load.

Author: cdavid
Content: It depends on the implementation. In C, it is quite easy to have n != n optimized away when compilers have their compiler flags set on. That's why you should use isnan to test nan instead of any other techniques when using C or C++.
